--- title: Matching property rights and transboundary ecological processes subtitle: The case of Norwegian salmon aquaculture authors: - name: Adams Ceballos-Concha corresponding: true orcid: 0000-0003-3822-8791 email: aceballos@ufl.edu - name: Frank Asche - name: Andrew Ropicki keywords: - Ownership concentration - transboundary externalities - spatial-dynamic externalities - aquaculture - salmon farming - property rights abstract: > Environmental management is significantly challenged by transboundary ecological processes, like spread of pests and diseases. This paper investigates whether aligning property rights with the spatial scale of these processes through ownership concentration can improve management outcomes. As a case study, we analyze farm-level data from 2012 to 2017 for the Norwegian salmon aquaculture industry, which has been affected by the transboundary spread of a parasite. We quantify ownership concentration within designated production zones using a Biomass Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (BHHI) and employ an instrumental variables approach to address endogeneity concerns. Our results indicate that increased ownership concentration significantly reduces sea lice levels conditional on an infestation being present (the intensive margin). A 100-point increase in BHHI is associated with an approx 15% reduction in sea lice. However, we find no significant effect of ownership concentration on the probability of a farm experiencing sea lice infestation (the extensive margin). The intensive margin results are robust to spatial and temporal correlation and potential departures from the strict exogeneity of the instrument. Although the precise mechanisms require further investigation, our findings suggest that concentrated ownership facilitates coordinated management strategies, internalizing the spatial externalities associated with sea lice dispersal. This study provides empirical evidence that market-based consolidation can serve as a self-enforcing mechanism for mitigating transboundary environmental challenges, though it may not prevent initial outbreaks. The findings highlight the importance of considering industrial organization when designing environmental policy for industries facing spatial-dynamic externalities format: revealjs: navigation-mode: vertical #incremental: true logo: images/IFAS-core.png #footer: "`emitanaka.org/slides/toronto2022`" slide-number: true multiplex: true theme: [simple, assets/monash.scss] show-slide-number: all controls: true width: 1280 height: 720 css: [assets/syntax-highlight.css, assets/custom.css, assets/pacman.css] header-includes: | execute: echo: true --- # Take-away message [1]{.circle} * Concentrated ownership improves management ::: info-box - Higher ownership concentration (measured via the Biomass Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (BHHI)) significantly reduces sea lice severity on farms already experiencing infestations, suggesting that coordinated management strategies enhance treatment efficacy. - 100‚Äêpoint increase in the BHHI is associated with approximately a 15‚Äì16% reduction in sea lice levels on farms already experiencing infestations. ::: # Take-away message [2]{.circle} * Limited impact on infestation occurrence ::: info-box The study finds no evidence that increased ownership concentration affects the initial probability of a sea lice outbreak, suggesting that preventive measures may require different strategies. ::: # {data-background-image="images/Picture7.png" data-background-size="cover"} ## [STORY 1]{.story} [üå± The folklore of fervent field experiments]{style="float:right;text-align:right;"} {background-color="#027eb6"} --- ## [STORY 1]{.story} üå± The folklore of fervent field experiments {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out"} :::::: {.columns} :::::: {.column width="37%"} ::: box Consider a field experiment in agriculture where plot are laid in out as 6 rows by 8 columns (each also called strip). <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
